title: How to Store Vegetables

steps.headline: Chill stalky vegetables in water.
steps.description: Cut the green tops off of carrots, radishes, beets, and celery, then place them in a container full of cold water until they’re just submerged. Leave the container on one of the central shelves in the refrigerator uncovered. When properly stored, the tough, fibrous veggies will keep for up to 2 weeks. Changing the water every 2-3 days will help prevent them from becoming slimy. A shallow water bath will prevent the tough veggies from drying out when exposed to the cold air in the refrigerator. Hold onto your beet and carrot greens—they can be sautéd and served as a scrumptious side dish.

steps.headline: Place cruciferous veggies in the crisper drawer.
steps.description: Keep crunchy broccoli, bok choy, cauliflower, and Brussels sprouts in the bag you bought them in or transfer them to another open container and put them away as-is. The crisper drawer is the best place for these items, as they do best in conditions that are cool but not bone-dry. If you’re worried about them drying out, lay a damp paper towel over the tops of the heads or leaves.

steps.headline: Store lettuce and cabbage dry.
steps.description: After rinsing the head with cold water, pat it dry thoroughly, then return it to its original bag and tie off the top. You can also put it in a separate large airtight container with a locking lid. The container can then go anywhere in the refrigerator that you have room. The same can be done for whole radicchio, as well. The more moisture present, the more likely the head is to turn brown and mushy.

steps.headline: Wrap leafy greens in a damp paper towel.
steps.description: Wet a layer of 2-3 folded paper towels under a cold tap, then squeeze out the excess water. Unfurl the paper towels and place the greens inside. Fold the edges over to cover them, then stick the entire bundle in a bowl or open container and place it in the fridge. This method works well for items like spinach, arugula, kale, basil, and pre-cut Romaine lettuce, as well as fresh herbs. If you don’t have an extra container to spare, slip a rubber band loosely around the bundle to hold it together.

steps.headline: Refrigerate bell peppers, cucumbers, and zucchini after a few days.
steps.description: These will typically be fine on the countertop for 2-3 days. After that, they can begin to wrinkle and grow soft. At this point, you’ll need to wrap them in a damp paper towel or place them in an open plastic bag and move them to your refrigerator’s crisper drawer. Crisp, juicy vegetables with tough skins don’t tend to last longer than about 2 days at room temperature. A trip to the fridge may buy them an additional 2-3 days at most.

methods.name: Storing Hearty and Seasonal Vegetables at Room Temperature

steps.headline: Remove the veggies from their original container.
steps.description: Keeping fresh produce in close proximity can cause it to spoil faster. For this reason, it's generally best to do away with plastic bags and boxes that can smother fresh vegetables and instead store them loose. If you're working with limited storage space, you can also use a large open container that promotes airflow, like a cardboard box or reusable mesh bag.

steps.headline: Find a cool, dark place for potatoes and other root vegetables.
steps.description: They’ll stay good for 1-2 weeks, as long as surrounding heat and light are kept to a minimum. Assuming you’ve run out of other storage options, try dumping them into a bucket or basket and tucking them away in one of the bottom corners of your pantry. A dim basement or earthen cellar can be ideal for potatoes. The same guidelines apply to sweet potatoes, turnips, and rutabaga.

steps.headline: Eat tomatoes and corn as soon as they’re ripe.
steps.description: Pick out tomatoes and corn while they’re still slightly green and let them reach peak freshness before eating or cooking with them. For most varieties, you’ll have 2-5 days to use them before they begin to show signs of going bad. If you buy them ripe, try to use them either the same day or the next. If for some reason you can’t enjoy your produce right away, place it in an open plastic or paper bag and stick it in the refrigerator, where it will keep for another 2-3 days.

steps.headline: Leave onions and garlic out on the countertop.
steps.description: These aromatic bulb veggies are covered in layers of thin, papery tissue that protect the good stuff inside from exposure to the elements. As a result, they don’t require any special treatment. Moving older bulbs to the crisper drawer or a cool, dark shelf in an out-of-the-way part of your pantry may buy them a little more time. Throw out unused onions and garlic once they grow limp and discolored or start to develop an overpowering sour smell.

steps.headline: Keep winter squash cool.
steps.description: As their classification suggests, hearty seasonal varieties of squash like butternut, kabocha, and sweet dumpling prefer cold temperatures. A dark pantry or kitchen cabinet is often a perfect place for them. You can even leave smaller specimens like acorn squash in the fridge for longer-term storage, if space allows. You may even be able to get away with stashing recently-harvested winter squash outside, as long as the temperature doesn’t fluctuate too much above or below about 50. The same storage advice also applies to pretty much all major species of pumpkins. Winter squashes can keep anywhere from 4 weeks to 7 months, depending on the size and species.

steps.headline: Monitor avocados closely.
steps.description: Avocados have a very narrow window of ripeness, which means they’re often stocked and sold while they’re still a little firm. Keep your avocados somewhere in plain sight where you can track their status. To test whether they’re ready to eat, give them a gentle squeeze. They should feel soft and pliable, but not mushy. If your avocados have already ripened and you haven’t yet used them, relocate them to the refrigerator to keep them alive for 3-5 more days.

methods.name: Keeping Your Vegetables Fresh for Longer

steps.headline: Store your vegetables away from your fruits.
steps.description: As fruits mature, they give off a gas called ethylene, which speeds up the ripening process. If you’re not careful, this can cause your veggies to go bad at much faster rate than they would otherwise. It’s especially important not to leave them bagged or in any other enclosed space together. Consider devoting one drawer in your refrigerator to fruits and another one to vegetables. Situate room temperature fruits and veggies at opposite ends of the counter to create some distance between them.

steps.headline: Allow your veggies to get some air.
steps.description: Vegetables require good ventilation, so punch a few small holes in the bag or container to promote airflow if they didn’t come equipped for this purpose. Space like items apart in the refrigerator, container, or countertop so they’ll have a little room to breathe. Airtight containers with zippers or locking lids aren’t ideal for most veggies, as they don’t allow for the necessary circulation.

steps.headline: Hold off on washing fresh vegetables.
steps.description: Rather than rinsing your produce as soon as you get it home from the supermarket, wait until you’re getting ready to cut, cook, or serve it. The cleaning process can cause changes in temperature and strip away protective coatings designed to help some veggies maintain their ripe conditions. Getting your veggies wet also makes it more likely for bacteria to grow on them. If it’s necessary to wash particularly dirty produce items (or you’ve already washed them without thinking), pat them dry thoroughly with a paper towel and leave them to sit out in the open for a couple hours before placing them in the refrigerator or a separate storage container.

steps.headline: Freeze vegetables until you’re ready to use them.
steps.description: If you’re ever in doubt about how to store a particular type of item, make the freezer its new home. The majority of vegetables have a high enough water content to make freezing a viable storage option. That way, you won’t be forced to throw them out or use them up in a hurry. Make sure the item is clean, dry, and tucked away in an airtight freezer bag or lidded jar before putting it up. The frigid temperatures of the freezer can often preserve fresh veggies for as long as a year.
